title-group.article-title: Analysis of sandwich plates: A three-dimensional assumed stress hybrid finite element

article-meta.aff: Department of Civil Engineering, Istanbul Technical University, Istanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Kutlu Darılmaz, ITU, Department of Civil Engineering, 34469 Maslak, Istanbul, Turkey Email: darilmazk@itu.edu.tr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An eight-node assumed stress solid element with rotational degrees of freedom is employed for analyses of sandwich plates consisting of stiff face and a comparatively flexible core material with the aim to accurately and efficiently capture stresses. The element formulation is based directly on an eight-node element. This direct formulation requires fewer computations than a similar element that is derived from an internal 20-node element in which the midside degrees of freedom are eliminated by expressing them in terms of displacements and rotations at corner nodes. The formulation is based on Hellinger-Reissner variational principle. Numerical examples are presented to show the validity and efficiency of the present element.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sandwich composite plates are being increasingly used in fields of modern technology and industry since they combine high bending stiffness with low weight. A good understanding of their structural and dynamical properties and also an accurate knowledge of deformation characteristics, stress distribution and natural frequencies are needed. Recently, usage of sandwich plates has become even more attractive due to the introduction of advanced composite materials for the stiff layers (faces) and low-density materials for the flexible layers (cores). The faces take compressive and tensile loads and the core transfers shear loads between the faces while providing high bending stiffness.
There have been extensive research carried out in the past years to investigate the behaviour and design of sandwich plates.

Ramtekkar et al. [1] presented a layerwise three-dimensional mixed 18-node finite element and employed for the evaluation of transverse stresses in sandwich laminates. Icardi and Atzori [2] presented a mixed eight-node solid element for analysis of local effects in laminated and sandwich composites. Nayak and Shenoi [3] developed a family of plate bending elements containing nine degrees of freedom (d.o.f) per node based on a refined higher order shear deformation theory and carried out parametric studies to study the behaviour of length-to-thickness ratios, boundary conditions, fiber orientations on vibration and buckling of composite and sandwich plates. Linke et al. [4] formulated a displacement-based finite element for static and stability analyses of sandwich plates using a three-layer sandwich model. Kim [5] developed two enhanced plate theories for laminated and sandwich plates via the mixed variational formulation for free vibration analysis. Oh et al. [6] developed a finite element formulation based on an enhanced first-order shear deformation theory to accurately and efficiently predict the behaviour of laminated composite and sandwich structures. Zhang and Yang [7] reviewed the recent developments of the finite element analysis for laminated composite plates. Moreira et al. [8] proposed a high-performance hexahedral finite element based on the application of the enhanced assumed strain method for non-linear geometric and material analysis of sandwich structures. Malekzadeh and Sayyidmousavi [9] studied the free vibration analysis of rectangular sandwich plates with a flexible core with and without a uniformly distributed attached mass on the top facesheet. Amichi et al. [10] presented a 3D finite element sandwich plate for vibration analysis of unsymmetrical sandwich plates with a viscoelastic core. Morozov and Lopatin [11] proposed the analytical closed-form solution providing the value of fundamental frequency of the CCCF (three edges clamped, one edge free) composite sandwich plates by using Hamilton’s principle in conjunction with the first-order shear deformation theory. Wu et al. [12] proposed a higher order theory satisfying the interlaminar stress continuity and extending the theory presented on eight-node isoparametric element.

An important issue in the analysis of sandwich plates is predicting the transverse normal and shear stresses accurately. In sandwich plates problems where the analyst is interested in the prediction of stresses accurately, 3D solid elements and multilayer elements are usually used for these problems. In this study, an eight-node assumed stress solid element with rotational d.o.f developed by author Darılmaz [13] is employed and applied to the analysis of sandwich plates to accurately capture stresses that could affect the load-carrying capacity.

sec.title: Element stiffness formulation
sec.p: The assumed-stress hybrid method is based on the independent prescriptions of stresses within the element and displacements on the element boundary. The element stiffness matrix is obtained using Hellinger-Reissner variational principle. The Hellinger-Reissner functional of linear elasticity allows displacements and stresses to be varied separately. This establishes the master ﬁelds. Two slave strain ﬁelds appear, one coming from displacements and one from stresses.

The Hellinger-Reissner functional can be written as (1) where {σ} is the vector of assumed stresses, [S] is the material compliance matrix relating strains, {ε}, to stress ({ε} = [S]{σ}), [D] is the differential operator matrix corresponding to the linear strain-displacement relations ({ε} = [D]{u}) and V is the volume of structure. In equation (1), the load potential is omitted as it is not required for formulating the element stiffness matrix.

The assumed stress field is described in the interior of the element as (2) and a compatible displacement field is described by (3) where [P] and [N] are matrices of stress and displacement interpolation functions, respectively, and {β} and {q} are the unknown stress and nodal displacement parameters, respectively. Intra-element assumed stresses and compatible displacements are independently interpolated. Since stresses are independent from element to element, the stress parameters are eliminated at the element level and a conventional stiffness matrix results. This leaves only the nodal displacement parameters to be assembled into the global system of equations.
Substituting the stress and displacement approximations equation (2), equation (3) in the functional equation (1) yields (4) where (5) (6)
Now imposing stationary conditions on the functional with respect to the stress parameters {β} gives (7)
Substitution of {β} in equation (4), the functional reduces to (8) where (9) is recognized as a stiffness matrix.
The solution of the system yields the unknown nodal displacements {q}. After {q} is determined, element stresses or internal forces can be recovered by use of equations (2) and (7). Thus (10)

The displacement field of the element is defined by treating the edges as beam elements with shear deformation. Formulation of rotational d.o.f for the present element is based on the procedure given by Yunus et al. (1991) for their displacement based hexahedron and tetrahedron elements. For the typical edge i-j shown in Figure 1 the displacements can be expressed as (11) where (xi yi zi) and (xj yj zj) are the coordinates of joints i and j, respectively, with respect to the reference local element xyz coordinate system. Equation (11), when extended to all sides of the element, indicate that 24 rotational d.o.f. in addition to the usual 24 displacement d.o.f. are required to express the displacements as quadratic functions. As opposed to conventional eight-node solid elements, which have 24 d.o.f, elements with rotational d.o.f have 48 d.o.f. Figure 1.
Proposed element.

The biggest difficulty in deriving hybrid finite elements seems to be the lack of a rational methodology for deriving stress terms, Feng et al. [14] It is recognized that the number of stress modes m in the assumed stress field should satisfy (12) with n the total number of nodal displacements, r the number of rigid body modes and p the number of zero-energy modes in an element. If equation (12) is not satisfied, use of too few coefficients in {β}, the rank of the element stiffness matrix will be less than the total degrees of deformation freedom and the numerical solution of the finite element model will not be stable and produces an element with one or more mechanisms.
Increasing the number of βs by adding stress modes of higher order term, each extra term will add more stiffness and stiffens the element, Pian and Chen [15] and Punch and Atluri [16].

In determining the stress field, each of the stress components was represented by seven independent parameters. A complete linear stress field was first chosen for each stress component and for the quadratic terms, the higher order terms containing the coordinate direction in which the stress component acts were suppressed. This type of selection was found to yield better results from numerical experiments, Yunus et al. [17] For the element under consideration n = 48, number of rigid-body modes = 6 and number of zero-energy rotation modes = 6. Thus, the number of deformation modes = 48–6–6 = 36. To suppress the deformation modes, the minimum number of stress modes is 36. From numerical experimentations, the author achieved that the following 42 parameter selection of stress field is somewhat more accurate and less sensitive to geometric distortion than fewer parameter selections.
The assumed stress field in the natural coordinates is given as (13)
Symbolically (14)

The stress field assumed in natural space is transformed to the global system using a natural-to-global tensor transformation matrix (15) where [T] is the transformation matrix at the element origin and can be expressed as (16) (17) Jij terms are the components of the Jacobian matrix evaluated at the element origin.

The element stiffness matrix with rotational d.o.f exhibits equal-rotation mechanisms. These mechanisms were suppressed by artificially adding a small energy penalty to the stiffness matrix to make the stiffness matrix non-singular by generalizing the 2D stabilization schemes of MacNeal and Harder [18]. This method was also used by Yunus et al. [17] for their displacement-based hexahedron and tetrahedron elements.

Consider any face of the element and assume that the face lies in a local x¯-y¯ plane, Figure 2. A relative rotation θ¯r is defined to be the difference between the average of the out-of-plane nodal rotation θ¯ and the average rotation θ¯o determined directly from the element shape functions as (18) where n¯, θ¯i are the number of nodes for the face and out-of-plane rotation at any node i, respectively. θ¯o is the rotation at the element center and can be defined as (19) Figure 2.
Equal rotation and zero translation mode.
In terms of face system nodal d.o.f u¯i,v¯i,θ¯i (20) where {q¯}, [Φ] are face system nodal unknowns and relative rotation in terms of face system unknowns, respectively.
The energy penalty Λ is (21)
Here, γ is a dimensionless constant (γ = 10–6 is recommended), V is the element volume and G is the shear modulus.
The vector of local face system unknowns {q¯} is related to global element d.o.f by (22) where li, mi and ni are direction cosines of the local face system.
Symbolically equation (22) is written as (23)
The relationship for all face unknowns {q¯}with the related global unknowns {q} can be written as (24)
Equations (21) and (24) can be combined (25) where (26)
The penalty stiffness [Kr] is added to the existing element stiffness matrix [K] and the resulting stiffnes matrix is free from spurious equal rotation and zero translational modes.

sec.title: Element mass matrix
sec.p: The problem of determination of the natural frequencies of vibration reduces to the solution of the standard eigen value problem [K]-ω2[M]=0, where ω is the natural angular frequency of the system. Making use of the conventional assemblage technique of the finite element method with the necessary boundary conditions, the system matrix [K] and the mass matrix [M] for the entire structure can be obtained.
Element mass matrix is derived from the kinetic energy expression (27) where {q·} denotes the velocity components and [R] is the inertia matrix.

The nodal and generalized velocity vectors are related with the help of shape functions (28) Substituting the velocity vectors in the kinetic energy, Equation (18) yields the mass matrix of an element. (29) (30) where [m] is the element-consistent mass matrix and is given by (31)

sec.title: Numerical examples
sec.p: Some numerical examples have been used for assessing the accuracy of the proposed element. The results obtained are compared with theoretical and some other element solutions that are available in open literature.

sec.title: Example 1
sec.p:
A simply supported sandwich plate, Figure 3, subjected to uniform pressure load for which an analytical Reissner solution for the central displacement and moment taking into account transverse shear deformation is available. Central deflection value is obtained and compared with analytical and Tenek and Argyris [19] solutions. Figure 3.
Geometric and material properties of sandwich plate.

Results, given in Table 1, are in a good agreement with other solutions. Table 1.
Central displacement for a simply supported sandwich plate
W (mm)
Tenek and Argyris19 31.22
Present study 31.18
Analytical 31.4537

sec.title: Example 2
sec.p: Free vibration analysis of a simply supported plate having fiber reinforced polymer face sheets and polyvinyl chloride foam core is solved. The results of present element are compared with analytical result of Malekzadeh and Sayyidmousavi [9]. Material properties for facesheet are taken as E11 = 24.51 GPa, E22 = E33 = 7.77 GPa, G12 = G13 = 3.34 GPa, G23 = 1.34 GPa, ρ = 1800 kg/m3, ν = 0.078 and for core E11 = E22 = E33 = 0.10363 GPa, G12 = G13 = G23 = 0.05 GPa, ρ = 130 kg/m3, ν = 0.32. Geometric properties of the plate is a/b = 1, a/d = 10, dc/d = 0.88. Here a and b are the dimensions of the plate and d and dc represent the the total thickness and the core thickness, respectively.

Results given in Table 2 showed that the behaviour of the present element is satisfactory and results are in a good agreement with other solutions. The first four mode shapes of the plate are depicted in Figure 4. Figure 4.
First four mode shapes of simply supported square plate. Table 2.
Dimensionless natural frequencies ϖ=(ωa2/d)(ρc/Ec) for a simply supported square plate (0°/90°/0°/core/0°/90°/0°)
Mode Analytical Nayak et al.20 Malekzadeh and Sayyidmousavi9 Present element
1 14.83 15.04 14.74 15.10
2 26.91 28.10 27.36 25.44
3 27.47 29.20 27.36 25.94
4 35.57 37.76 36.39 33.58

sec.title: Example 3
sec.p: A square clamped sandwich plate with lamination 0°/90°/core/0°/90° and subjected to uniformly distributed load qo on its top surface has been considered. The materials of the facesheet are E1 = 90.121 GPa, E2 = E3 = 7.303 GPa, G12 = G13 = 4.134 GPa, G23 = 2.68 GPa, ν12 = ν13 = 0.28, ν23 = 0.34 and core material properties E1 = E2 = 0, E3 = 2.076 GPa, G13 = 0.358, G23 = 0.122, G12 = 0 ν12 = ν23 = ν31 = 0. Following normalization factors have been used

The individual thickness of the top and the bottom face sheets is 1/10 of the total thickness of the sandwich plate. Variation of the transverse shear and the normal stresses through thickness are presented in Figure 5(a)–(c) and those of the transverse shear and the normal strains are presented in Figure 6(a)–(c) and compared with Ramtekkar et al. [1] Due to the large difference in the shear modulus of the face and the core material, a high stress difference in the magnitude of the transverse stress in the face sheet region and that at the core region has been observed. It shows the necessity of a refined three-dimensional finite element analysis for such problems. Figure 5.
Variation of normalized (a) transverse normal strain (εz); (b) transverse shear strain (γxz); (c) transverse shear stress (γyz) through the thickness of a clamped square sandwich plate (0°/90°/core/0°/90°) with a/d = 5, subjected to transverse uniformly distributed load on top surface. Figure 6.
Variation of normalized (a) transverse normal stress (σ¯z); (b) transverse shear stress (τ¯xz); (c) transverse shear stress (τ¯yz) through the thickness of a clamped square sandwich plate (0°/90°/core/0°/90°) with a/d = 5, subjected to transverse uniformly distributed load on top surface.
Results showed that the behaviour of the present element is satisfactory and results are in a good agreement with other solutions.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An assumed stress solid element with rotational d.o.f is presented for analysis of sandwich plates. Comparison of the results with previous studies validates the element and indicates its application to analysis of sandwich plate problems and also presented element is capable of obtaining the transverse normal and shear stresses accurately.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
